article: I was reading a notice at the entrance to my college dormitory, when a girl came up to me and said, Do you _ a quarter? I m one short of putting my laundry in the dryer. I _ to think about it for a few seconds and considered whether I d be _ to give a quarter away. I found myself _ her, thinking about why she didn t _ four quarters down from her room with her, as if she had _ to be one short so she could ask someone else for it. (Later I knew _ that was not the case.) But I didn t have any reason to _ her. Then I responded, Yeah, I think I have the only one, though fully _ that I had three. Here you go, I said with a smile. Thanks, she responded, _ that she could have clean clothes to wear the next morning. A few moments later the girl _ and gave a dollar bill to me. Why are you giving this to me? I asked, _ . Oh, because you were kind to me, so I m just giving back the _ . It s just a dollar, but I felt it was _ . More so because I hadn t given that quarter with such nice _ , the way she gave that dollar to me. I felt like it was the first time I ever _ something greater in return for something so _ that I had given. I saw the power of kindness and generosity in a _ way. I thought it was so worth giving that quarter away. Giving and _ don t usually happen hand-in-hand, _ when it does, like it did this time, it makes one think about why generosity is so powerful in the first place.
